case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City I v. Jubilee Mills Ltd., Bombay

facts.text: The judgment was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the companyrt was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J. - This is an appe

facts.text: This is an appeal on a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Bombay against the judgment of the High Court dated March 13, 1958

anchor.surface_text: - This is an appeal on a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Bombay against the judgment of the High Court dated March 13, 1958, on a reference made by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City I, is the appellant and Jubilee Mills Ltd., Bombay, is the respondent

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City I, is the appellate and the Jubilee Mills Ltd., Bombay, the respondent.

facts.text: The assessee company is a limited liability company with a paid up capital of Rs. 15,25,000

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany is a limited liability companypany with a paid up capital of Rs. 15,25,000.

facts.text: Paid up capital composition: Rs. 10,00,000 ordinary shares of Rs. 10 each, Rs. 1,25,000 5,000 cumulative preference shares of Rs. 25 paid up, Rs. 4,00,000 4,000 second preference shares of Rs. 100 each fully paid up

anchor.surface_text: Its paid up capital is made up as under Rs. Rs. 1 lakh ordinary shares of Rs. 10 each 10,00,000 5,000 cumulative preference shares of Rs. 25 paid up 1,25,000 4,000 second preference shares of Rs. 100 each fully paid up 4,00,000

facts.text: Second preference shares do not entitle the holders to vote. Voting shares are 1,05,000

anchor.surface_text: The second preference shares do number entitle the holders to vote. Thus shares of the assessee companypany carrying votes are 1,05,000.

facts.text: Position on June 30, 1947 for assessment year 1948-49 corresponding to previous year ended June 30, 1947

anchor.surface_text: This was the position on June 30, 1947. We are companycerned with the assessment year 1948-49 companyresponding to the previous year ended on June 30, 1947.

facts.text: Company assessed on total income of Rs. 7,47,639. Tax calculated at Rs. 4,20,548

anchor.surface_text: In that year, the companypany was assessed on a total income of Rs. 7,47,639. The Income-tax Officer calculated the tax at Rs. 4,20,548.

facts.text: Company declared dividends aggregating Rs. 24,750

anchor.surface_text: The companypany, however, declared dividends which is the aggregate amounted to Rs. 24,750.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer applied section 23A and deemed dividend of Rs. 3,97,788 with previous approval

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, with the previous approval of section 23A, of the Income-tax Act and held that the companypany was deemed to have declared dividend of Rs. 3,97,788.

facts.text: Assessee managed by firm Mangaldas Mehta & Co. consisting of 14 partners, 7 of whom were directors

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany was being managed by a firm called Mangaldas Mehta Co. That firm companysisted of fourteen partners of whom seven were the directors of the assessee companypany.

facts.text: Directors who are partners held 35,469 ordinary shares and 880 first preference shares

anchor.surface_text: The members of the managing agents who were also directors held between them 35,469 ordinary shares and 880 first preference shares.

facts.text: Other 7 partners held 41,659 ordinary shares and 370 first preference shares

anchor.surface_text: The remaining seven members of the managing agents, who were number directors of the assessee companypany, held respectively 41,659 and 370 shares of the two categories.

facts.text: 75 shares held by Girdhardas Co. Ltd. to which section 23A applicable

anchor.surface_text: Seventy-five shares were held by Girdhardas Co. Ltd., to which companypany admittedly section 23A was applicable.

facts.text: Company incurred heavy losses, reconstructed capital in 1930 due to debit balance of Rs. 12,75,000 in P&L account

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in the past the assessee companypany incurred heavy losses and it had to reconstruct its capital in 1930 because it had a debit balance of Rs. 12,75,000 in the profit and loss account

facts.text: Capital reconstruction by reducing ordinary shares from Rs.100 to Rs.10, preference from Rs.100 to Rs.25 after High Court approval

anchor.surface_text: which had to be paid out of capital. This was done by reducing the face value of the ordinary shares from Rs. 100 to Rs. 10 each, and of the preference shares from Rs. 100 to Rs. 25, each after obtaining the approval of the High Court.

facts.text: ITO granted rebate of one anna under proviso (a) to paragraph (b) of Part I of Second Schedule of Finance Act, 1948

anchor.surface_text: It also appears that the Income-tax Officer granted to the assessee companypany a rebate of one anna under proviso  a  to paragraph  b  of part I of the second schedule of the finance Act. 1948.

facts.text: High Court answered first two questions in affirmative, third unnecessary

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by the judgment under appeal, answered the first two questions in the affirmative and in view of the answer to question No. 2 it companysidered it unnecessary to answer the third.

facts.text: Managing agents hold 77,128 out of 1,00,000 ordinary shares plus 1,250 first preference shares

anchor.surface_text: Applying the above test to the present case, it is clear that the managing agents between them hold 77,128 out of 1,00,000 ordinary shares, well above the limit. They have in addition 1,250 first preference shares out of 5,000

facts.text: Total holding including Girdhardas 78,453 shares, 75% of voting shares is 78,750

anchor.surface_text: To this must be added 75 shares held by Girdhardas Co. Ltd. to which section 23A is admittedly applicable. This brings the total holding to 78,453. 75 of the total shares bearing votes is 78,750.

facts.text: Category C: 9,899 ordinary shares and 937 first preference shares held by directors on behalf of minors/families

anchor.surface_text: Some of the members of the managing of the managing agency firm held on behalf of their minor children or on behalf of their families 9,899 ordinary shares and 937 first preference shares.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court answer, answered second question in negative

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was number right in answering the second question in the affirmative. The appeal is allowed. The answer of the High Court is set aside and the question is answered in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: Section 23A before its amendment in 1955, in so far as it is material, read as follows 23A. Power to assess individual members of certain companypanies. - Where the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that in respect of any previous year the profits and gains distributed as dividends by any companypany up to the end of the sixth month after its accounts for that previous year are laid before the companypany in general meeting are less than sixty per cent. of the assessable income of the companypany of that previous year, as reduced by the amount of income tax and super tax payable by the companypany in respect thereof he shall, unless she is satisfied that having regard to losses incurred by the companypany in earlier years or to the smallness of the profit made, the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would be unreasonable, make with the previous approval of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner an order in writing that the undistributed portion of the assessable income of the companypany of that previous year as companyputed for income tax purposes and reduced by the amount of income tax and super tax payable by the companypany in respect thereof shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividends amongst the shareholders as at the date of the general meeting aforesaid, and thereupon the proportionate share thereof of each shareholder shall be included in the total income of such shareholder for the purpose of assessing his total income Provided further that this sub-section shall number apply to any companypany in which the public are substantially interested or to a subsidiary companypany in which the public are substantially interested or to a subsidiary companypany of such a companypany if the whole of the share capital of such subsidiary companypany is held by the parent companypany or by the numberinees thereof.

concepts.interpretation: Applies unless company in which public substantially interested; ITO applied deeming dividend of Rs.3,97,788

anchor.surface_text: Explanation. - For the purpose of this sub-section, - a companypany shall be deemed to the a companypany in which the public are substantially interested if shares of the companypany  number being shares entitled to a fixed rate of dividend, whether with or without a further right to participate in profits  carrying number less than twenty five per cent, of the voting power have been allotted unconditionally to, or acquired unconditionally by, and are at the end of the previous year beneficially held by the public  number including a companypany to which the provisioned of this sub-section apply , and if any such shares have in the companyrse of such precious year been the subject of dealings in any stock exchange in the taxable territories or are in fact freely transferable by the holders to other members of the public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Managing agents and associates hold more than 75% voting power; public does not hold 25% unconditionally and beneficially.

holdings.text: Section 23A applies to the assessee company as it distributed less than 60% of assessable income as dividends and is not a company in which the public are substantially interested.

anchor.surface_text: The only question raised in this appeal is the application of section 23A of the income tax to the assessee companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts satisfy conditions of s.23A; public not substantially interested per Explanation.

holdings.text: A company is one in which public are substantially interested only if shares carrying not less than 25% voting power (excluding fixed dividend shares) allotted/acquired unconditionally and beneficially held by public; equivalent to no individual or group acting in concert holding more than 75% voting power controlling company affairs.

anchor.surface_text: This companyrt pointed out that what one has to find out is whether there is an individual who, or a group acting in companycert which, companytrols or companytrol the affairs of the companypany to the exclusion of others by reason of his or their voting power. Such person or group of persons do number answer the description public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Supreme Court's decision in Raghuvanshi Mills Ltd. (1961) 41 ITR 613 and Privy Council in Bjordal; directors qua directors part of public unless in controlling group.

holdings.text: The partners of the managing agency firm (Mangaldas Mehta & Co.) constitute a group acting in concert holding more than 75% of voting power (77,128 ordinary shares + 1,250 first preference + 75 Girdhardas + category C shares).

anchor.surface_text: Applying the above test to the present case, it is clear that the managing agents between them hold 77,128 out of 1,00,000 ordinary shares, well above the limit. They have in addition 1,250 first preference shares out of 5,000

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shareholdings in categories A, B, C by partners/directors; common interest as managing agents implies control; >75% threshold met.

holdings.text: Shares held by managing agents' partners as guardians/karta for minors/families (category C: 9,899 ordinary, 937 first preference) count towards group holding as voting power exercised by partners themselves.

anchor.surface_text: But when we turn to category C we find that 6,000 shares were held by the members of the managing agency on behalf of minor children and the voting power arising from these shares was in their own hands as guardians.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voting power not unconditional/beneficial by public; controlled by group members.

holdings.text: No direct proof required that group acted in concert; sufficient if circumstances (e.g., managing agency partners' common interest for mutual gain) indicate they must act together per human experience.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing a point was raised that it has to be proved as a fact that the persons constituting the group, which owns shares carrying more than seventy-five per cent. of the voting power, were acting in unison.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inference from structure and share concentration; managing agents cohesive for profit maximization.

holdings.text: Managing agents holding >75% voting shares control company affairs, can appoint directors as nominees; such group not part of 'public'.

anchor.surface_text: Normally, managing agencies are number informed by parties except for the purpose of mutual gain and the companymonness of the interest lends a companyesion to the body which enables it to act in its own interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Where holding small, other evidence needed; but >75% proves control over directors.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bjordal and held that though the directors, qua directors, do number cease to be members of the public, the holding of the group of fourteen individuals who companylectively formed the managing agency firm of Mangaldas Mehta Co. Could number be companynted as held by the member of the public in this case for purposes of the Explanation. The Tribunal was further of the opinion that this group of persons had a juristic personality and it should be taken into account as a group in determining where the companytrolling power vested according to the test laid down by the Privy Council in the said case.

precedents.cited_proposition: directors qua directors do not cease to be members of the public; group of persons forming managing agency has juristic personality for determining controlling voting power

precedents.citation: Raghuvanshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax

anchor.surface_text: Raghuvanshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax. In that case the High Court had held that directors, qua directors, must be companytrasted with the public and if the directors held more than 75 per cent. of the voting power then alone the companypany interested. The High Courts view was that the managing agents act under the direction of the directors and unless the directors were themselves companytrolling the voting power above the limit stated by the Explanation, the companypany must be regarded as one in which the public were substantially interested.

precedents.case_name: Raghuvanshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: directors qua directors contrasted with public; if directors hold >75% voting power, company not substantially interested in public

precedents.citation: Thomas Fattorini Lancashire Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners

anchor.surface_text: Thomas Fattorini Lancashire Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners they refused to take action under section 66 4 . The High Court took numberice of the fact that the privy companyncil in Bjordals case had indicated a test to determine what is meant by public which was different from that indicated by them in Raghuvanshi Mills case. They, however, held that after 1950, the decisions of the Privy Council had only a persuasive authority and the decision of the High Court was binding in the absence of a decision by this companyrt.

precedents.case_name: Thomas Fattorini (Lancashire) Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: refusal to allow supplemental statement of case under section 66(4)

anchor.surface_text: 1961 41 I.T.R. 613. This companyrt pointed put that by the words unconditionally and beneficially is indicated that the voting power arising from the holding of those shares should be free and number within the companytrol of some other shareholder and the registered holder should number be a numberinee of another. It was pointed out again by this companyrt in Shree Changdeo Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax that by unconditional and beneficial holding is meant that the shares are held by the holders for their own benefit only and without any companytrol of another.

precedents.case_name: Raghuvanshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: unconditionally and beneficially means voting power free and not controlled by another; holder not nominee
precedents.cited_holding: voting power arising from shares held unconditionally and beneficially should be free from control of others

precedents.citation: Shree Changdeo Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: Shree Changdeo Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax that by unconditional and beneficial holding is meant that the shares are held by the holders for their own benefit only and without any companytrol of another. This companyrt approved the decision of the Privy companyncil in Bjordals case that directors, qua directors, are number without the pale of the public. This companyrt pointed out that what one has to find out is whether there is an individual who, or a group acting in companycert which, companytrols or companytrol the affairs of the companypany to the exclusion of others by reason of his or their voting power.

precedents.case_name: Shree Changdeo Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: unconditional and beneficial holding means shares held for own benefit without control of another
